Storage

Suitable for various types of data, economical and reliable cloud storage, provides a high assurance of security, lasting and stable storage, and the capability of rapid and flexible expansion.

Apply for trial Purchase now

Azure Storage is a kind of highly durable, available and scalable cloud storage enabling your access anytime, anywhere.

We charge customers the Azure storage space fees according to the storage capacity, number of storage transactions (number of storage read or write operations), and data already transmitted.

Storage is divided into five types:

Block Blob: Block Blob is a cost-effective, expandable method that can be used for reliably storing mass Blob data. Typical instances include: data sharing, mass data and backup.

Documents: Documents allows the VM of Azure Data Center to install a shared document system by SMB agreement, and access the document system via the standard Windows file API. The virtual machine can be connected to these document systems simultaneously, permitting you to easily share permanent data between different roles and instances. You can also access your data using the Windows file API or document REST API.

Page Blob and disk: Page Blob provides block storage for random access and frequent updating/optimization. Thanks to high performance, durability and reliability, it can be used as the permanent disk for the VM in Azure.

Tables: Tables are a kind of highly scalable and easily available NoSQL database. These provide storage-based key values for structured data and semi-structured data.

Queue: Queue provides a reliable message transfer system used to plan asynchronous tasks, and realizes permanent message transfer.

In addition, we provide four redundant storage levels:

Local redundant storage (LRS): We maintain multiple copies of data in a zone so as to provide high durability.

Geo-Redundant Storage(GRS): We asynchronously provide extra data durability through replication between two zones hundreds of miles apart in the same territory. In the two zones, we maintain multiple copies of the data.

Read and Access Geo-Redundant Storage (RA-GRS): In addition to GRS services, we provide read-only access to the storage account in the auxiliary zone (which has a final edition consistent with the data in the main storage system). When the storage account in the main zone is not available, the customers can use this service to access the data.

Zone Redundant Storage (ZRS): In addition to storage of three copies like LRS, the ZRS space will replicate data asynchronously between data centers of one or two zones, so as to improve the durability of LRS.

Azure Hosting Drive is a new and recommended disk storage product used for Azure Virtual Machine, enabling permanent data storage. Multiple hosting drives can be used for every virtual machine. Hosting Drive provides two types of lasting storage options: Advanced Hosting Drive and Standard Hosting Drive.

If you’re interested in the pricing details of the non-hosting drive, please refer to the Non-Hosting Drive and Page Blob pricing details page.

Advanced Hosting Drive

Advanced hosting drive, based on a solid state drive (SSD), aims to support I/O intensive workloads with extremely high throughput and low delay. With the help of Advanced Hosting Drive, we can set a permanent drive and configure its size and performance characteristics.

The total expenses of Advanced Hosting Drive depends on the disk size and quantity, and is subject to the outgoing data transmission. The drive size provides different Input/Output operations/per second (IOP), throughput limit and monthly price/per GB. We can select the most appropriate options including storage size, IOP and throughput. We can add several permanent disks onto the VM and configure up to a 64 TB storage space for every VM. The disk throughput of every VM can reach up to 80,000 (per second of input/output operations) and 1600 MB/second, with a reading delay of less than 1 millisecond. Advanced Hosting Drive is supported exclusively by the DS Series, DSv2 Series and FS Series VM sizes.

Operation and Data Transmission Pricing

If the transactions of Page Blob are not performed by a virtual machine, billing is done by the transaction. For every transaction, a single operation shall be considered as write, read or delete for billing. If the size of the read or write is more than 64 KB, an extra read/write (IO) expense will be charged for every excess of 64 KB, and 15 IO expenses are charged at most for every transaction. If the size of transactions is more than 1 MB [64 KB x (1 transaction + 15 IOs)], other IOs are not charged irrespective of the size of transactions.

FAQs

Expand All

Common

  • Is apportioning cost proportionately required if I just use storage services a few days per month?

    Yes. Storage capacity is charged by the average data storage (using GB as the unit) per day within a month. For instance, if you’ve continuously used 10 GB of storage capacity in the first half of the month, but haven’t used any storage capacity in the second half of the month, the average storage of 5 GB must be charged.

  • How do I know which data redundancy option I am using (see the text above)?

    You may select redundancy in creating a storage account. After creation is complete, you may check the redundancy by using Azure Portal or the service management API.

Blob Storage

  • What is a Blob storage account and what are the differences between this account and a general purpose storage account?

    A Blob storage account is exclusively used as the storage account for Blob storage data, such that customers can assign access layers according to the data access frequency in the account. General-purpose storage accounts can be used for storing Blob, documents, disks, tables and queues.

  • Has the price of Block Blob for general purpose storage account been changed?

    No. The price of Block Blob in general purpose storage account hasn’t yet been changed. Please check the Block Blob Pricing page.

  • When checking Azure billing, how can we distinguish if paying for the Blob in the Blob storage account or general-purpose storage account is required?

    If “Hot” or “Cold” exists in the resources name, it means this expense is related to the Blob storage account. For instance, if it shows, “Standard IO - Cold Block Blob (GB)”, it means you use the Blob storage account and need to pay for this account, while “Standard IO – Block Blob (GB)” is charged in relation to the Block Blob in the general-purpose storage account.

  • What are “Hot” and “Cold” access layers and how do we ascertain which one is to be used?

    In the Blob storage account, we could set the Blob’s access layer as “Hot” and “Cold”. The storage GB price increases in the sequence of “Cold” and “Hot” layers, and the data access expense increases in the sequence of “Hot” and “Cold” layers. The “Hot” and “Cold” layers are separately applied to data with almost no access and occasional access, and the availability service level agreement of these data has a lower requirement. If you don’t know the access mode of data, it’s recommended that you should use the “Hot” layer for at least one month in the beginning, then decide if it’s necessary to shift to “Cold” storage to save on costs where applicable.

  • Is paying the data writing expense required when switching the Blob storage account from “Cold” to “Hot”?

    We will charge for data retrieval from the Blob storage account when it’s switched from “Cold” to “Hot”. For instance, if the Blob storage account has 100 GB of data, when the account is switched from “Cold” to “Hot”, you will be charged with a data retrieval fee of 100 * ¥0.0657 = ¥6.57.

  • Is paying for data writing required when the Blob storage account is switched from “Hot” to “Cold”?

    No. Paying for data writing is not required when your account is switched from “Hot” to “Cold”. If you write data directly into the “Cold” access layer of the Blob storage account, only paying the data writing expense is required.

  • What is the Geo-replication data transfer cost?

    When you write data into a GRS account, the data will be replicated into another Azure Zone. The Geo-replication data transfer expense refers to the bandwidth cost of replicating data on another Azure Zone.

Disk Storage

  • If I add an empty 100 GB disk onto my VM, are you charging me the entire 100 GB expense or just the storage space expense I used?

    If the empty 100 GB disk is supported by an advanced storage account, you will be charged for a P10 (128 GB) disk. If you use any other types of storage account, only the storage space for storing data written into the disk will be charged, irrespective of the allocated disk size.

  • Is the service level agreement cover advanced storage, the same as other storage services?

    Yes. 99.9% read/write availability is also available for advanced storage accounts.

Hosting Drives

  • If I add an S10 or P10 drive onto the VM, are you charging me the expense of total amount shown above or just the expense of the storage space I used?

    The allocated disks are charged at the same rate irrespective of the disk space used.

  • The price shown is the monthly price. How do you charge if the hosting drive is used for less than 1 month?

    It’s charged by hours and percentage according to the monthly price.

Document Storage

  • If I create sharing with a 5 TB limit, are you charging me the entire 5 TB or just the cost of the used storage space?

    Only the used storage space is charged for, rather than the allocated limit.

Support and Service Level Agreements

If you have any questions or need any help, please access Azure Support and select self-help services or any other method to contact us for support.

We guarantee that we can successfully process data reading requests from an offsite redundant storage (RA-GRS) account at least 99.99% of the time (99.9% for the Cold Access Layer), but provided that we shall retry in the secondary zone from the data writing failure from the primary zone.

We guarantee that we can successfully process data reading from onsite redundant storage (LRS) and offsite redundant storage (GRS) accounts at least 99.9% of the time (99% for the Cold Access Layer)

We guarantee that we can successfully process data writing requests into onsite redundant storage (LRS) and offsite redundant storage (GRS) accounts and read and access geographically redundant storage (RA-GRS) accounts at least 99.9% of the time (99% for the Cold Access Layer).

To learn more about the details of our server level agreement, please visit the Service Level Agreement page.

The hosting disk itself doesn’t provide a service level agreement with financial support. The availability of the Hosting Drive depends on the service level agreement governing the basic storage used and the virtual machine it’s attached to. To learn more about the details of the service level agreement of the Hosting Drive, please visit the Hosting Drive Service Level Agreement page.
